content.description: Stand at the lip with sloping features. From there, work up the arete to the generous features, and mantel atop the boulder.
content.protection: A pair of pads. The landing has a few rocks that makes it uneven.
content.location: It climbs the east side of the boulder's southeast arete.

content.description: Sit start with bumps on the arete. From there, reach the large feature (which seems like it could break but I fully weighted it and it held), commit to the arete above, gain the featured lip, and mantel atop the boulder.
content.protection: A pair of pads. The landing is good, but there is a large boulder directly behind it (which actually provides a good spot if you have it padded).
content.location: It climbs the east side of the boulder's northeast arete (though I did top it out on the north side).

content.description:
Sit start as far underneath the overhang as possible with each hand on the prow's opposing edges.  From there, slap and compress your way straight out, where you'll eventually reach the lip and the subsequent solid topout using the large jugs.

The first move is likely the crux, as the starting foot position can be deceptively slick.
content.protection: The problem is low-ball, a pad may get in your way.  The landing is great here nonetheless.
content.location: This is on the West face prow on Dragon Rock.
